sect2.title: About
sect2.para: These functions allow you to obtain information about classes and instance objects. You can obtain the name of the class to which a object belongs, as well as its member properties and methods. Using these functions, you can find out not only the class membership of an object, but also its parentage (i.e. what class is the object class extending).

sect2.title: An example of use
sect2.para: In this example, we first define a base class and an extension of the class. The base class describes a general vegetable, whether it is edible or not and what is its color. The subclass Spinach adds a method to cook it and another to find out if it is cooked.

example.title: classes.inc
example.programlisting:
<?php

// base class with member properties and methods
class Vegetable {

    var $edible;
    var $color;

    function Vegetable( $edible, $color="green" ) {
        $this->edible = $edible;
        $this->color = $color;
    }

    function is_edible() {
        return $this->edible;
    }

    function what_color() {
        return $this->color;
    }
    
} // end of class Vegetable


// extends the base class
class Spinach extends Vegetable {

    var $cooked = false;

    function Spinach() {
        $this->Vegetable( true, "green" );
    }

    function cook_it() {
        $this->cooked = true;
    }

    function is_cooked() {
        return $this->cooked;
    }
    
} // end of class Spinach

?>

sect2.para: We then instantiate 2 objects from these classes and print out information about them, including their class parentage. We also define some utility functions, mainly to have a nice printout of the variables.

example.title: test_script.php

sect2.para: One important thing to note in the example above is that the object $leafy is an instance of the class Spinach which is a subclass of Vegetable, therefore the last part of the script above will output:

informalexample.programlisting: [...] Parentage: Object leafy does not belong to a subclass of Spinach Object leafy belongs to class spinach a subclass of Vegetable

refnamediv.refpurpose: Call a user method on an specific object

refsect1.title: Description

refnamediv.refpurpose: Checks if the class has been defined

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function returns true if the class given by class_name has been defined, false otherwise.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the name of the class of an object

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function returns the name of the class of which the object obj is an instance.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns an array of class methods' names

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function returns an array of method names defined for the class specified by class_name.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns an array of default properties of the class

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function will return an array of default properties of the class.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns an array with the name of the defined classes

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function returns an array of the names of the declared classes in the current script.

note.para: In PHP 4.0.1pl2, three extra classes are returned at the beginning of the array: stdClass (defined in Zend/zend.c), OverloadedTestClass (defined in ext/standard/basic_functions.c) and Directory (defined in ext/standard/dir.c).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns an associative array of object properties

refsect1.title: Description

refnamediv.refpurpose: Returns the name of the parent class of an object

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function returns the name of the parent class to the class of which the object obj is an instance.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Determines if an object belongs to a subclass of the specified class

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function returns true if the object obj, belongs to a class which is a subclass of superclass, false otherwise.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Checks if the class method exists

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This function returns true if the method given by method_name has been defined for the given object, false otherwise.
